Award.AwardTitle: A Hierarchical Multiscale Method for Nonlocal Fine-scale Models via Merging Weak Galerkin and VMS Frameworks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Many problems in the natural sciences and engineering involve phenomena that possess a spectrum of material, spatial, and temporal scales which correspond to coarse and fine scale physics. Very often fine scale physics is also nonlocal and therefore these problems pose a great challenge to the current computational techniques. Nonlocality of fine-scales and advecting sharp gradients are two key ingredients in the modeling of several classes of fluid dynamics problems. This research effort focuses on the development of variationally based methods for problems with steep gradients and discontinuities in the underlying fields and wherein fine scales have a nonlocal feature. Of specific interest are propagating steep fronts for which interacting discontinuities challenge the stability of the numerical methods. Typical examples are chemically reacting fluids permeating through porous elastic solids where fast reaction rates produce steep concentration fronts. Such problems arise in (i) high temperature injection molding of fibrous composites in micro and nanomaterials engineering, and (ii) enhanced oil recovery and secondary shale gas recovery processes in petroleum engineering. Another class of problems from mathematical physics is advection dominated viscous flows leading to anisotropic turbulence.

The PI will develop a unique and novel, simultaneous top-down and bottom-up multiscale approach for consistent representation of both the hierarchy of scales as well as the structure of inter-scale coupling operators for complex fluid mechanics problems. It blends ideas from the Variational Multiscale (VMS) method that helps decompose the governing system of equations into coarse-scale and fine-scale sub-problems and then employs Weak Galerkin (WG) ideas at the fine-scale variational level to extract models for the finer physics. Weak continuity of functions that is facilitated by the Weak Galerkin method results in fine-scale models that are nonlocal. A further generalization of WG via Discontinuous Galerkin (DG) ideas provides a framework to develop methods for problems with sharp gradients on sound mathematical basis. This notion leads to variationally derived Discontinuity Capturing (DC) methods that are independent of the user-defined or user-designed parameters. Emphasis is placed throughout on variationally consistent interscale coupling with rigorous treatment of the continuity conditions that are critical for the mathematical and algorithmic stability. The resulting computational algorithms will be ideal for massively parallel computing on distributed systems where message passing traditionally has been a bottle neck. The variational structures underlying the new methods will increase local-solves that are cost effective because of local resident memory on the new generation of processors while substantially reducing global communication between processors, thereby leading to efficient and economic computations. The mathematical frameworks and computational algorithms emanating from this work will be broadly disseminated by publication in high-quality archival journals, and by presentations at high impact conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Physical phenomena involving steep gradients that traverse through the domain are ubiquitous in science and engineering. Commonly observed problems in flow physics include sharp advecting fronts in chemically reacting flows, mixing flows of immiscible multiphase fluids, and steep gradients and discontinuities in high-speed flows. Weak and strong discontinuities also arise in nonlinear modeling of materials that develop discrete damage at the finer spatial scales, namely, micromechanic damage in crystalline materials and interfacial damage in multi-constituent engineered materials. In all these problem classes, the highly localized phenomena invariably have global implications and therefore pose challenge to the numerical methods because of the associated wide rage in spatial and temporal scales.

This project has led to new developments in the underlying mathematical constructs of numerical methods for the class of elliptic and parabolic problems that can develop steep gradients and propagating weak and strong discontinuities. The new class of methods called Variational Multiscale Discontinuous Galerkin (VMDG) methods are developed by embedding Discontinuous Galerkin (DG) ideas in the Variational Multiscale (VMS) framework. The VMS framework helps decompose the governing system of equations into coarse-scale and fine-scale sub-problems. This provides the flexibility to apply Discontinuous Galerkin (DG) approximations and Weak Galerkin (WG) approximations directly at the fine-scale variational level to extract models for finer physics that is otherwise not adequately modeled by the coarse-scale variational constructs. These variationally derived models are then be embedded in the coarse scale formulation facilitated by VMS, thereby giving rise to numerical methods with enhanced stability and accuracy properties.

In year-1 of the project these ideas were explored in the context of elliptic problems with strong discontinuities, and then extended to nonlinear elasticity. The new method was employed to investigate interfacial debonding in multi-constituent materials at finite strains. With success on elliptic problems, these ideas were explored in the context of parabolic problems in year-2 where weak and strong discontinuities were directly embedded in the space of fine-scale functions. The resulting method, termed as the Variational Multiscale Discontinuity-Capturing (VMDC) method, was tested on advection dominated flows, multi-phase flows with jumps in pressure and/or concentration fields, and on problems that involve mixing flows of immiscible incompressible fluids. The stability and accuracy of this method was investigated on the classical Rayleigh-Taylor instability problem which is important in several engineering and science disciplines. These mathematical developments were further generalized in year-3 to singularly perturbed Diffusion-Reaction equation that develops sharp internal and boundary layers. The discontinuity enriched fine-scale models led to stabilization tensors that are naturally endowed with discontinuity capturing structure. In the regions with thin layers and sharp gradients, these variationally projected fine-scale models augment the stability of the coarse-scale formulation to accurately capture sharply varying fields. Since these methods rely on local enrichment of functions, they are easily implementable in the finite element context. Stability proof and convergence analysis were carried out to show the mathematical attributes of the methods. The insights gained from elliptic and parabolic equations helped extending the VMS framework to develop a systematic procedure to variationally derive closure models for turbulence.

The new mathematical methods developed during the course of this project provide a unified variational framework that transcends the traditional fluid and structural mechanics sub-disciplines and yields formulations with enhanced stability and accuracy properties. These methods will benefit a range of engineering and science disciplines and will serve as building blocks for investigating core technical issues in the broad class of problems that are of significance in the areas of infrastructure, environment, energy, and medicine.
